div1.p: Griffitts writes about the anopheles survey at Badin, North Carolina.

div1.head: Letter from T.H.D. Griffitts to Lunsford D. Fricks, October 21, 1920
div1.opener:
COPY
Health Survey
Reporting Survey Reservoir,
Tallassee Power Co., Badin, N. C.
U. S. Public Health Service,
Norfolk, Va.,
October 21, 1920.
Surgeon L. D. Fricks,
Medical Officer in Charge,
Malaria Investigations,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Memphis, Tennessee.
Griffitts
1920
Sir:
div1.p:
In compliance with instructions in your letter of October 1,
1920, I spent October 4th, 5th and 6th, making a survey of Anopheles
conditions on and near the lake of the Tallassee Power Company at
Badin, North Carolina.

It is quite obvious that an examination of conditions made at
this time - there has been light frost and the nights for ten days or
more have been cool - cannot well be compared with that of 1919, when
the examination was made during the 4th week of August. However, two
apparent changes in this body of water in general have taken place
which should have effected a reduction in Anopheles production, the
present season - (a) a lessened amount of floatage, and (b) a decided
increase in the number of minnows (gambusia affinis) destructive to
mosquito larvae. Very few gambusia were observed in the lake last year,
but in addition to the natural increase, the Company, after the inspec-
tion of last year, established a minnow hatchery and from this they have
been able to add large numbers to the reservoir this season. The follow-
ing observations during the survey October 4th - 6th are taken from
field notes:
A.

1. Oct. 4th. Beaver Dam Creek. Examined the bight south of Ferry
(#. side near Roe Hall's), near lumber pile. In 25 dips collected 7
large A. larvae and 1 A. pupa. In Hall's barn near, 8 Anopheles quad.
and in his house 6 Anopheles quad. (Note: last year, Aug. 21, 32 A. Q.
in this house). One child sick now, said to be malaria. Hall states
all of family (7) had malaria this year.

2. Meadow in front of P. P. Elliott's and just east of Roe Hall,
breeding A. 11 in small pools and hoof prints. At head of bight of lake
this area drains into breeding A 11.

3. Swamp in pasture between D. M. Elliott and L. F. Hinson, A.111
breeding. Caught 3 Anopheles punct. on wall of spring nearby. (Hatching
from this area last year 100% Anopheles puncts.) Hinson's hog shed
near - 6 Anopheles quads. and 6 Anopheles puncts. This within one-
half mile of bight of lake nearest J. C. Elliott's.

4. J. C. Elliott's claim to have all had malaria this summer.
Did not examine house for Anopheles but in stable found 6 Anopheles
quads., and 6 A. punct. Dipped from spring branch near J. C. Elliott's

A 11. Dead trees standing in this bight and much floatage, especially
pinebark. Minnows (gambusia affinis) in considerable numbers observed
here.

5. Oct. 5th. Glady Fork. (Near J. F. Hamilton place) House
(now vacant) one-quarter mile away. Breeding of Anopheles in bight-
A all sizes and pupae. Standing dead trees and brush and much
debris and floatage in places. No Anopheles images found in any of
the vacant houses.

6. N. M. Thayer (or Hamilton) Place. Bight of Glady Fork
near big sawdust pile. Recent rains (5 days before) have carried
down much debris to head of bight, and here breeding A ;;;. A branch
enters here, and it is probable some, at least, of the larvae were
washed down into the pond. This collection, then, should show a high
percentage of Anopheles punctipennis. Along the shoreline near the
pile of sawdust only light breeding.

7. Rocky Creek. On G. W. Henderson place. Swiftly flowing
stream, scoured by rain by days ago. No breeding found. A;; in
drift and floatage at head of bight where this stream enters pond.
Top minnows numerous here.

8. Glady Fork. In front of W. R. Russell's (G. W. Henderson's
place) Anopheles breeding in fair number where not recently washed
out.

9. Virgil Coggins's place. Pools in hog lot near house
breeding Anopheles profusely (A ;;;) In mule stall 4 Anopheles quads.
in cow shed 5 Anopheles punct., one Anopheles quad., Coggins says
he has lived here all his life and never had “chills” until two years
ago. His boy had “chills” in 1912.

10. Roby Coggins. Near head of Beaver Dam Creek, east side.
Extensive flat area of pond, shallow water, growth of bulrushes. Out
of 40 dips in selected places, only one Anopheles larvae. At spring
nearby A ;;; as many as 10 at a dip. This latter place not connected
with reservoir.

11. At abandoned road on Barne's place, near head of bight
of lake (1/4 mile north of “10” in floatage, anopheles -- and pupae,
300 feet above this are overflow pools in which breeding of anopheles
;;. This latter not connected with lake. Valley above flat. Sub-
ject to overflow and potential anopheles area.

12. Alexander Coggins' Place. Mr. Coggins says he now has
malaria. Three bed rooms searched and found one anopheles quad. None
in stables.

14. E. J. (Quillan) Elliott. In house, four Anopheles quad.,
in barn one A. punct. Spring and branch near breeding Anopheles freely.
Pool at old saw-mill place, negative. Oil on the water here. Bight
with much standing timber, log jam, debris and floatage near new sheep
pasture fence and within one-half mile of E. J. Elliott's breeding very
freely (A;;), and an important place.

15. Whitney. Pool on W. side of railroad North of Southbound
Ry. depot, breeding very freely (A ;;), all sizes and pupae. This part
of the pond was examined last year and is producing Anopheles in much
greater numbers now.
B.

1. With a rather uniform house infestation by Anopheles quadrim-
aculatus, though at this time a light infestation - and a rather free
breeding of Anopheles in the portions of the lake, particularly the
bights, examined, it would point to a common production area. In August
of 1919 the development from the larval collections from the lake was
100% quadrimaculatus; from the fresh (small streams) and rain water
collection 100% Anopheles punctipennis. From our knowledge of the
breeding habits of the two species, the opinion is justified that the
pond has again produced A. quads., this season, though perhaps in reduced
numbers.

2. It is my opinion that malaria is endemic about portions of
the environments of the lake. What part of the lake has played in this
incidence is difficult to estimate. I think it is well for all
concerned to concede that the lake is responsible for a considerable
amount of Anopheles breeding close enough to occupied dwellings to
cause infestation by Anopheles. Likewise, a very definite amount of
Anopheles breeding is occurring outside of the lake and in several
insstances in places much closer to the occupied dwellings, as shown
under “A#”.

3. Efforts to control anopheles production should be applied
to (a) the portions of the lake, its bights, etc., within, say one mile
of occupied residences, where anopheles breeding occurs; (b) streams,
swamps, pools, etc. in and about the premises of the people in this
area where anopheles breeding occurs.

4. By the making of this lake, or reservoir, Anopheles production
has been increased in some areas, while in others, such production places
have been destroyed. As to the latter, there seems little room for
doubt, but that Palmerville, for instance, has been benefitted decidedly.
Prior to the impounding this settlement had quite an Anopheles infesta-
tion and malaria, produced principally in parts of the old French canal.
The lake covered these places. Malaria is said to have practically
disappeared from Palmerville. The town of Badin situated immediately
adjacent to the lake is said to be free from malaria.
5. It is suggested that the following measures be enforced.

(a) The shore line of the reservoir, its branches, bights
and indentations shall be cleared of brush, trees, underbrush and
the like, so that stumps and other projections which at any stage of
the water will not extend beyond or sufficiently near the surface of
the water so as to collect and hold logs, drift, debris and floatage
in such places as to endanger the health of the people through the
production of mosquitoes.

(b) The formation or existence of log-jams and collections
of drift, debris, floatage and the like in narrow valleys, bights
or indentations of the reservoir where wave action is absent or weak
and where the production of mosquitoes resulting from such condition
would endanger the life and health of the people shall be prevented
or removed or treated in such manner and at such times as to prevent
the development of such mosquitoes.

(c) Areas slightly or partially covered with water, where
cattails, bulrushes and similar vegetation grow and constitute A.
breeding places so as to endanger health, shall, if the conditions c
cannot be remedied by raising and lowering the water level be made
free from vegetation or treated with oil, or both if necessary, the
oil to be applied once every ten days in such manner as to prevent
anopheles production.

(d) The reservoir shall be stocked with fishes or minnows
(such as Gambusia affinis) known to be destructive to the eggs and
larvae of mosquitoes, and every effort shall be made to protect them
against their enemies and to secure their successful propagation and
increased numbers in the reservoir, its branches, bights and inden-
tations.

Respectfully, (s) T.H.D. Griffitts,
Epidemiologist. Copied Nov. 18th-20.F.
